item.description: The Rev. Emily Scott was a high-school student in the mid-1990s when she decided to make her faith her career. A gay couple exchanged vows in her family's Seattle church, even though same-sex unions hadn't yet been officially sanctioned by the Episcopal Church. "That was a key moment for me in understanding what church was about," Ms....

item.title: Staying is the New Going
item.description:
Staying is the New Going

Uploaded by Frontline Church Planting on 2015-08-31.

item.title: How We Gather - A New Report On Non-Religious Community
item.description:
How We Gather - A New Report On Non-Religious Community

My colleague Angie Thurston from the Harvard Divinity School and I published a report this week about the nature of millennial non-religious communities. Have a read! How We Gather

item.title: Pop-Up Shabbat: A Dinner Community Case Study
item.description:
Pop-Up Shabbat: A Dinner Community Case Study

Pop-Up Shabbat is a pop-up restaurant inspired by Jewish culture and tradition in Brooklyn, NY. Each gathering lasts 3-4 hours and includes "slightly socially engineered mingling, family-style dining, music (yes, sometimes dancing), and a bit of Shabbat tradition."

item.title: Data Mining Reveals the Four Urban Conditions That Create Vibrant City Life
item.description:
Data Mining Reveals the Four Urban Conditions That Create Vibrant City Life

Back in 1961, the gradual decline of many city centers in the U.S. began to puzzle urban planners and activists alike. One of them, the urban sociologist Jane Jacobs, began a widespread and detailed investigation of the causes and published her conclusions in The Death and Life of Great American Cities, a controversial book that proposed four conditions that are essential for vibrant city life.

item.title: Why Jesus' Skin Color Matters
item.description:
Why Jesus' Skin Color Matters

That he was an ethnic minority shapes how we minister today.

item.title: Kevin Doi | Building Churches that Value Neighborhood, Place, Community, Justice, Healing & Mission | The GlobalChurch Project
item.description:
Kevin Doi | Building Churches that Value Neighborhood, Place, Community, Justice, Healing & Mission | The GlobalChurch Project

Graham Hill & Kevin Doi discuss building churches that value neighborhood, place, community, justice, healing and mission. Kevin Doi is the founding pastor of Epic Church and co-founder of JOYA Scholars, a non-profit organization inspiring and preparing students from the Garnet Neighborhood in Fullerton toward higher education.

item.title: Theologians study Seattle for future of 'church'
item.description:
Theologians study Seattle for future of 'church'

Theologians and sociologists are paying close attention to churches in Seattle. KING 5's Alison Morrow shows us why. SEATTLE -- The Pacific Northwest is often called the "None Zone" because of the number of people who claim no religious affiliation. Yet, theologians and sociologists are paying close attention to churches in Seattle.

item.title: Is Seattle the Birthplace of a New Religion?
item.description:
Is Seattle the Birthplace of a New Religion?

Easter happens early this year, and on that Sunday morning, my church-a progressive mainline Protestant congregation in a youthful Seattle neighborhood-will overflow with people of all ages. This story begins the Sunday after, when the crowd has thinned and visibly aged.

item.title: Jesus Dust: Jesus' Last Meal: A Maundy Thursday Reflection
item.description:
Jesus Dust: Jesus' Last Meal: A Maundy Thursday Reflection

You've heard it called by many names: The Last Supper. Communion. The Lord's Table. Eucharist. The Holy Mass. But it's a meal that Jesus would have simply called "the Passover." My first experience with the Passover was during my junior year in college, I had decided to fast for a couple of days before Easter as a way of mourning the sadness of Jesus' death.
